Definition: You have been given a comment from some user from the dataset of civil comment, categorize the comment on the basis of toxicity into Neglible/Low/High.

Positive Examples.input: That, sir, is a slur against all dicks!
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment here has words 'slur' and 'dicks' that have derogatory connotations in the comment. Hence, it is a positive example
The comment is highly offensive against Jewish people. Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.input: Bell media is garbage and paying for satellite or Cable is a waste of money.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment does not have any explicit curses or derogatory words in it. The words 'garbage' and 'waste' have negative tone but not toxic enough to be classified highly toxic. Therefore, this is a negative example.

Negative Examples.input: Apologies.  Her name is Hasselberger.  As far as I can tell, she will neither be in Guam or a part of the proceedings.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment doesn't have any curse words in it, however it is toxic because based on subject's name 'Hasselberger' a toxic judgement has been made. Therefore, this is a negative example.

No, her status as a public employee is legally relevant. The UO lawyers are examining case law and statutes regarding the out-of-work behaviors of employees in public organizations, regarding free speech. The issue is not intent; it is the effect on the workplace. The UO can easily make the claim that even if it has no specific policies about blackface or a similar behavior, the act is racist and impacts the workplace. The UO has policies regarding racist behavior. 

Your conflation of blackface and the confederate flag is often used by those who mistakenly claim an absolute right to free speech, which does not exist. The U.S. Supreme Court has decided on that repeatedly. But you missed the point. It's not about intent. You seem to believe intent is central to the legal adjudication of every potential offending behavior or act. You also seem to be confusing intent with motive, for which there are very real legal distinctions; as there are between criminal and civil law for both.

Actually Johnson does have a small but real chance of winning:  

If the election is close and Johnson wins at least one state, he can in fact win.  Why?

If no candidate wins 270 electoral votes, the House of Reps chooses between the THREE candidates with the most electoral votes.

In other words if Johnson won AK and New Mexico, Stein won Vermont and Trump and Clinton won the rest (but neither won 270).  The House would choose between Clinton, Trump and Johnson - and would almost certainly choose Johnson.

(This situation could also occur is Clinton or Trump won 270+ delegates in the election but there were enough Democratic Delegates felt the Bern and/or  Republican Delegates Dumped Trump - to push them below the threshold).

The majority of the members of the House are Republicans.
No Democratic Rep. is going to vote Trump.
No Republican Rep. is going to vote Clinton - BUT
Plenty of Republicans would prefer Johnson to Trump.
All of the Democrats would prefer Johnson to Trump.

Am I missing something, because there's nothing about the "free-range, organic, cruelty-free" section that appeared to be joking, or have any self-deprecating self-awareness, which is what this whole deal hinges on. Are there any commenters who are going to call the supervisor on this obvious distortion? 

I think this email-leaking parent did exactly the right thing. If a teacher has been assigning something like this for 20 years, there's no point in "confronting her directly". If her supervisor comes up with the line that defends her free-range, earth-friendly snobbery was "a joke", there's no reason to talk to anyone at the school about this assignment (clearly the entire administration sees the mind-numbing cognitive dissonance in labeling a cake full of sugar "earth friendly" and "cruelty free"). Leak it to the WW, and see what happens: Lo and behold, suddenly the creativity-loving food snob changes her tune.

There's nothing wrong with advocating for creativity (though I personally am skeptical of elementary school creativity proselytizers). There's absolutely nothing wrong with using and advocating "earth friendly" and "human healthy" ingredients.  But a middle school teacher - even one who lives in Portland - has no credentials to know what these ingredients are, and no right to push parents of her students to make financial lifestyle decisions based on the teacher's personal moral stance on branding and labeling of chicken and wheat products. In any case, she's recommending they make cakes out of cookie or brownie or cake batters. The number 1 or 2 ingredient is going to be some form of sugar, which is probably the worst thing you could eat, health-wise, and "plantation-consciousness"-wise, anyway.

It's easy to increase natural resources per person by limiting immigration. It's not clear that the same is true for financial resources. Personally, I'd rather be able to afford an HTC phone made in Taiwan, a PS4 made in Japan, a ThinkPad made in China, and maybe someday a Tesla made in the USA. If that means giving up a piece of arable land in return, I'm quite okay with that.
Immigration keeps importing young, hardworking people whose taxes and demographics sustain our welfare system. Wind power does work, but it's very site-dependent. The power in wind is also a cube of the wind speed... and wind speed increases the higher you go. This is why turbines that work are tall (120'+ to get away from ground turbulence), and are sited in spots that have *constant* wind... ideally 7mph or more. I'm sure no one wanted 120' towers at this site, but that's really the way to get wind power... but even then, this site doesn't always have wind. Along Ediz Hook would be a better location (as long as turbines didn't interfere with approach to airport out there)

An option for this park site given its occasional wind could have been solar PV panels; 3kW of PV panels (about 12 panels) might have cost $15k and would be generating electricity already, because all commercial PV components are UL listed. The ROI on PV these days is maybe 10 years with minimal tax / production incentives, (5 to 7 years with incentives) and the maintenance is minimal... no moving parts!

First, there will be no consensus regarding what to included in the list or regarding how to express included matters. The better view is that (a) the Criminal code, etc, establishes the basic no-nos, and (b) the public school system and establishing good community links to help settle and integrate immigrants will succeed as with earlier immigrant communities.
